pages.text: Dobermans have two genes that affect how they look, the B Locus and the D Locus. The B Locus determines whether the dog has red or black fur, while the D Locus may dilute the dog's coloration. All of these dogs feature rust points.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black fur, while the 'b' allele creates red fur. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the red trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for red pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either red carriers or red puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The D Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'D' and the recessive 'd'. The 'D' allele does not affect the coat's color, while the 'd' allele is a dilute that creates pale fur, called fawn on red dogs and blue on black dogs.
pages.title: D Locus

pages.text: Dogs with one copy of 'd' will carry the dilution trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for diluted pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'd' will always create either dilute carriers or diluted puppies.
pages.title: D Locus Cont.
